I saw this movie in theaters when it first came out. I got the sense that most of the people watching with me were cursing themselves for wasting five bucks and two hours.I, however, was struggling to contain my laughter at what was one of the best comedies of that summer.The lines are corny. The people are caricatures. The acting is over-the-top. The plot is full of giant holes and even bigger clichés. And yet, somehow, the people on the screen seem to be taking it all seriously. It's hilarious. The only thing that could possibly make it better would be the MST3K crew... but they'd almost be redundant.In short: It's so laughably bad, it's actually good.To make it even better, the action sequences and visual effects (particularly by the standards of the time) are pretty good.If you're looking for a serious Sci-Fi disaster movie, don't bother.If you're looking for an overtly funny parody of a Sci-Fi action movie starring Will Smith... Go watch MIB.If you're looking for more subtle humor in which the entire cast collectively acts as the straight man, spiced with some pretty cool giant explosions, see ID4. And get ready to laugh!

Review title: This is the movie that makes you cry and laugh at the same time
Review_body: This movie is the best of 1996.  I own the movie and watch it over and over. I love this movie.  It is the best Will Smith movie I have ever seen.

This movie is so unbelievably stupid that it's quite funny, actually.  I myself am not a great fan of science fiction,  and movies like ID are reason for that.  I gave it 2 out of 10 , 1 point for it's special effects - no surprise here. Lately Hollywood treats us with mega productions loaded with spectacular computer generated  scenes, but lacking good story, character development, and convincing acting.

Review title: Americans save the world once again - NICE!
Review_body: I was 14 when I first saw this movie and I liked it very much. Still I don´t think it´s a bad film. I have always liked science fiction and war movies, and this was both. The special effects were awesome, especially the huge spaceships above the cities. But why did I give ID4 only 6 points? The characters were quite shallow, that´s the biggest problem. And I can´t help but I find the american patriotism somewhat comical in the movie. Last time, for example, when I watched it, I ended up laughing my head off during the president´s speech. It was fun, yes, but I don´t think it was meant to be that way. But, if you like sf-movies with nice special effects, this movie is absolutely worth watching.

This movie was at MOST, average.  And that's only if you're willing to ignore the incredibly horrible plot, and all the holes therein.The part that makes it at least somewhat tolerable is the special effects. They had a great team on this one.  Now... how come they couldn't put those people, or people like them, to work on the plot?The basic idea is simple:  A race of aliens come to earth to conquer it, and the human race fights back.The problem with this film is HOW the humans fight back.  Using 50 year old alien technology, Jeff Goldblum, a satellite TV repairman, creates a computer virus to shut down the mothership's shields.  Apparently, this "Advanced" race of alien beings use Macintosh Computers, never upgrade their software, or change their passwords, or try to communicate with ships that are trying to dock, before allowing them to dock.Then there's the Hillbilly crop duster, played by Randy Quaid, who jumps himself into an F-18 Hornet, and is able to fly it, quite well, right away. I don't care if he was in the Korean War, or whatever... you don't just sit yourself into an advanced tactical fighter, without previous training and an understanding of all the controls, and start flying right away.

This is NOT a great sci-fi movie, don't expect a great argument or incredible original aliens, even worst don't expect to believe everything you see in the movie(believe me I've never seen a mac so versatile, and I've seen plenty). You can expect a lot of action sequences, a couple of jokes, a few romantic scenes, and of course don't expect the good guys to get a scratch.

After turning off my DVD I was kind of wondering what kind of movie it was. Was it intended to be a comedy, parody, action or sci-fi ? I realized it was an action sci-fi that makes rational people laugh. The movie is swamped by plot holes, stereotypical characters and factual errors.  I like the idea of disabling the alien's computers by a computer virus, that was created without any research and uploaded to the mother ship via unknown interfaces. Who's gonna buy such a rubbish ? The creators absolutely ignored the gravity effects of such a huge ship residing at the orbit. An exclusive use of F-18's by earth defenders and their incredible (impossible) maneuverability is just one more example. On the other hand 3D effects were really nicely done and the scenes of alien space ships overshadowing the U.S cities were pretty impressive.

This is the worse film ever made: history is completely stupid and it is mistakes full. Physics and CS laws are completely forgotten. For example, aliens are mainly destructed by means of a computer virus: think at that: they have technology to travel faster than light and they have no antivirus!!!

Truly the most bad movie of the 90's: American patriotism all the way, silly conversations, a stupid and unreal script, bad actors... And like always the Americans will save us all at the end. In contrast to other continents which are pictured with people still living in the middle-ages :) (ex. the Japanese talking to the Americans during the invasion in a WOII alike setting, I just couldn't believe it when I saw this!) the whole movie is packed with pro-American details, subtle or less subtle.one plus point: the first 20 minutes are ok. after that moment, the movie turns in an awful experience :]2/10 is my verdict. even the graphics didn't save the movie. the same for the actors.otherwise, have fun and laugh! :)

I remember watching this as a little kid and it blew my mind!!! I love it. Now when i saw the special effects i thought the budget was 100 million as a kid because i saw New York get ripped to shreds by a massive fire wave! It was less!!! It was 75 million and the film looked like pure gold. Complaints are how unrealistic it was! One of them was that at one point the president of the united states of America is in a plane shooting down reptile looking aliens with invisible shields around an alien warship the size of new york. But whats even scarier is that in space there's an alien mother ship the size of the USA about to fire a gigantic laser to destroy all life of earth!!! wow! Now the reason i love this film is because of this destruction + will smith=greatest movie ever! if you don't care about story or realism but love carnage! this is the film for you!

America saves the world, again! I just loved the strong speeches and the american patriotism packed in this film. It's wonderful that the aliens happen to attack the world (USA) in time for the american independence day, so that the rest of the world also can celebrate this day.One of the best scenes is when the president jumps in to a plane of his own to fight like the true brave american he is. It's a pity every country doesn't have a leader like that. The ending with Jeff Goldblum designing a virus for the alien ships is just marvellous. How appropriate that the alien computer systems also are based on 1's and 0's like our human computers.2/10 (Battlefield Earth is 1/10)

Independence Day has no smart script, thats for sure. It actually has one of the silliest scripts I've ever seen.But still: It is a fantastic film.The film is very entertaining, epic and simply a perfect popcorn movie. It never tries to be intelligent and it never acts as if it was intelligent, wich is something that must be considered.ID4 doesn't want to bring us a smart and philosophical story, it doesn't want to make us think about anything after we left the cinema and for sure it doesn't want to make us think while watching the film.It is a pure popcorn film which wants only one thing: To deliver scales of destruction and battle unseen till that time. And thats what it did.I remember the day I saw this film in cinema and the first alien ship flies over the skyline of LA. I also remember the firestorm sequence and the aerial battle sequences. This film is just full of scenes that are as memorable as hardly anything else. Actually, this film contains some of the coolest scenes I've ever seen and I enjoy it every time I watch it again.A script is not everything in a movie, and the rest of the film is undeniable top notch.

Review title: Independence Day is one of the weakest "science fiction" films of all time!
Review_body: Many films are science fiction, Independence Day however is not one of them. Filled with horrendous special effects, terrible acting, over the top performances, and one of the most ridiculous endings of all time, I could simply not take this movie seriously one bit. It's a rip off of better and superior earlier science fiction films. I didn't care about any of the characters in this film, all of which were completely irritating and completely ridiculous at the same time. Count me as one of the many people who found this film to be completely terrible.Nothing, is remotely interesting in this film but explosions, and idiotic lines. I wanted a refund after seeing this in theaters back in 1996. Yes, it was that bad.

Review_body: I ;love this movie. Its not to be taken too serious but its a whole load of fun. From the get go its ALIENS!!!! and then its ALIENS Attack!!! Fun fun fun. Oh and the Area 51 part is great too. Will smith is perfect and Jeff Goldblum is his usual self.Did you know that the US military were going to supply all the army tanks, uniforms, and guns but pulled out when the director refused to cut the Area 51 part of the movie??? hmmmm interesting.Critics slam this film but its just a fun movie and you can watch it with the kids. the first thing anyone should do, before giving a score, is to try to identify what movie they are going to rate.as already perfectly stated by some other people this is a popcorn movie and its rating can only be 10 over 10. it's funny because it's predictable. it would not sound politically correct but this is the movie where an Alcoholic, an Afro-American and a Jew, save the world. with a little help from the President of the United States.this is what it is. predictable, funny, totally enjoyable.it can't be compared to any other science fiction movie with ET's invading Earth that take themselves seriously.

Nowadays, the genre of sci-fi blockbusters is an element of cinema which is best avoided. It is a far cry from Star Wars or Close Encounters of the Third Kind. In 1996, the big hit was Independence Day.Earth is invaded by aliens, who destroy major city after major city. The special effects are terrific at times, particularly the attacks on iconic landmarks such as the White House and the Empire State Building. The actors have fun in their roles, especially Jeff Goldblum and Will Smith as the satellite genius and amazingly talented pilot respectively.Roland Emmerich's film, although great fun, contains several unbearably cheesy moments. One which springs to mind is the President's call for the world to declare July 4 as their independence day. Many of the battle sequences, although visually great, seem unrealistic. The dialogue is also poor for the most part.Watching it now, many of the film's elements seem stereotypical, although it is difficult to tell if this is because of the several similar films since, trying to replicate the success of Independence Day. It is a prime example of the thrilling action films we have become accustomed to. Despite this, Independence Day offers more substance than its counterparts, and is at the forefront of the sci-fi blockbluster.

Review title: Fun, but supremely annoying if you're not American
Review_body:
If it wasn't for Will Smith, this film would be one of the most lavishly constructed jingoistic pieces of trash to have hit the screens.  Will's on top form in this one, particularly in his early dogfight sequence (one imagines that he was getting in some early practice for Ali...).The film is obviously aimed primarily at the American market, but if this is how Americans want to see themselves, then the rest of the world has a lot to worry about.  It's spectacularly self-centred at times (e.g. 15 spaceships over the world, at least 4 of which are over American cities!). The few foreign characters are reduced to cartoon caricatures of their nationalities (e.g. the two British pilots (shown in short 'cut-to' sequences) speak with the sort of public school accents that show up in American sitcoms all the time, such as the butler in 'Fresh Prince', & make most British people I know cringe).  At times it appears that the producers picked out nationalities that they assume are top-of-mind (Iraq, Israel, Japan, Russia & Britain feature most prominently) for the American audience (or at least fairly low-brow elements of it) and then sterotyped them.
I can accept that, in an American film, it's the Americans that save the world. But the impression you get from the film is that no-one else even TRIES to fight back.  Yes, the other countries do join in the fight, but NO-ONE else shows any initiative.  Would it have been disruptive to show the President consulting with the UN, or to show a Chinese or French plane being destroyed while trying to attack the space ship?Still, it seems silly to complain about national stereotypes in a film that's chock-full of all sorts of stereotypes.  I kept expecting Jeff Goldblum to start talking about chaos theory, and Judd Hirsch even manages to get in an 'Oy Vey'!  None of the writers or actors seem to have had to stretch too far, but Smith & Goldblum make an effective enough team.That said, I still quite enjoyed the film.  It's not high art, but at least it made me laugh.  Thanks Will...

It was made strictly to entertain, and for the millions that went to see it opening weekend, it did.Considering this was one of the biggest blockbuster of all time i think it proves that some people just want to have fun in a theater. I don't want to see some Academy Award winning movie every weekend. I want to drink my soda, have some popcorn and watch stuff blow up and in the end the US/world comes out on top.I'm disappointed in how many people don't understand this and continue to complain about it's bad acting, which wasn't that bad, Old predictable plot(If you where surprised by that when you saw it, I'm amazed you can type enough to write a bad review), and finally it's attempt and drama(which was a good attempt and at a handful of times worked). Nevermind all that, just have fun, that's why that made this film, and that's why it did so great.If you don't like it then, just sit down and watch face/off and stay away from Vin Desiel movies.

Review title: It Just Doesn't Get Any Worse Than This
Review_body: Before he became an over-inflated egotist, Will Smith was actually a likable guy. He was a fairly talented young rapper (DJ Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prince) and a gifted, comedic television actor ("The Fresh Prince"). It wasn't until he started starring in trash like "Independence Day" that his welcome began wearing thin. "Independence Day" does nothing to redeem Will Smith. In fact, 1998's bomb did more to reinforce the notion that Will Smith should have remained in television rather than going into motion pictures.But I can't pick on Will Smith for this mess alone: remember, it takes a village. In the case of "Independence Day", it took many months of pre-publicity and advertising to pitch this bloated, idiotic, absurd story to audiences. It worked, given the fact that its opening weekend grossed an astounding $36.1 million at the box office. But just because something is popular doesn't mean it's good. ("Independence Day flopped with critics.)Essentially a poor remake of H.G. Welles' "War of the Worlds", "Independence Day" offers the same story line with a few modern twists and variations on the original storyline. Yes, Roland Emmerich's version contains ground-breaking special effects--visuals that defied existing technologies at the time, rightfully winning awards for their breakthrough brilliance. But you get a much stronger remake of "War of the Worlds" with M. Night Shyamalan's far superior "Signs"--also loosely based on the original tale--sans the spectacular effects. Why? Because "Signs" gave us characters to actually care about and a claustrophobically atmospheric screenplay soaked in mystery and suspense. "Independence Day" merely assumes we are even the least bit interested in its characters and could care less about plausible plot development.By the time Will Smith and company take the helm near the end of this wreck, we are asked to believe they can figure out the same alien technology attacking the earth to stop the invasion. I didn't buy it. Neither should you.Leave "Independence Day" on the shelf where it belongs.

I must say, i remember the first time i saw this movie... it was the most amazing thing i had ever seen. Never before had the sight of alien invasion looked so realistic on screen. I movie was full of cool, big ships, casting shadows on everything as the came into the atmosphere. The whole experience was so realistic, it really made you believe it could happen. In short this is the best alien movie, anyone could watch, with anyone at anytime.The best thing about the movie showed the reactions of people around the world, to probably the biggest thing that had ever happened to earth. The TV news, the car jams, the president's message. Everything was so well done, that it just couldn't have been done better. It is also visually the most stunning movie since star wars. The technology is old, nothing new...but the whole ships coming and fighting scenes were brilliantly made.The movie has everything..good actors, good action, good storyline, good direction and of course a good end...
This is excellent entertainment cinema. It's not deep, it's not challenging. It's entertainment.

My, doesn't that title sound like a pop album. Anyway, this movie was misunderstood. First and foremost, it is a movie. Yes, it is unbelievable, but it is a movie! Second, America is usually considered the strongest country in the world, which I'm sure will be getting many arguments there, and the movie was made in (gasp) America, so naturally the focus would be in America. When you see a British film, where does it tend to take place? Uh... Britian? And who tends to be the protagonist? A British guy? Now, I know this may shock many people, but this was a good movie. It was very entertaining, suspenseful, and actually pretty clever (for what it was, don't worry). The special effects were amazing, and the acting was bearable (which is all you need in an action movie). They weren't trying to make a deep, philosophical movie, or important one for that matter. No, they were trying to make a movie. A summer blockbuster, and that is all. They exceeded that and made one that is still remembered 5 1/2 years later. Now tell me that isn't something. Name another movie from 1996 off the top of your head. I'd have to think about it, but this would be the first one to come to mind.Everyone probably knows the story by now, but just in case: Aliens invade Earth and blow the crap out of everything in existence there, well, except for some pretty people, and the world must stand against them. This movie does include other countries, granted it is for one scene, but many like this don't as if America is the only country in the world, i.e. Mars Attacks. The Americans have an alien ship, via the Roswell incident, and because of this, CD's and those crazy com-put-er things were invented. But also because of this, Will Smith and Jeff Goldblum (who is the best actor in the movie, I don't care what you say, he seems more like a real person than Will Smith or Bill Pullman, and he is a good actor. Oh no! This Craig guy is crazy for thinking that!) fly the ship to the mother ship, which is above the moon, and blow it up with a nuke. It is not the virus that destroys it, it is the nuclear missile that is shot inside of the ship. The virus just shut down the shields.The virus: It actually does make sense. The aliens took over using the satellites that we had for TV and such, so everything involved with them was not working well. Because they were using the satellites, all Jeff Goldblum had to do was hack into the satellite and that would let him into the alien's internet provider (which, ironically, was Earthlink) and give them a direct connection. So they emailed a virus to the aliens and bam! it destroyed their systems. Ever had a virus? It can be that bad. I believe Jeff went into the future and got the real Y2K virus, not the one that actually went out, the one in the crappy TV movie that made computers explode into people's faces and kill them. So the virus, which could have just as easily been uploaded by a PC, made their computers crash. The Technical guys could not come in time to fix it, because all they had was a few minutes to fix the computers, and they had to have their Starbucks or their day would just suck. And then, BOOM! Jeff and Will barely escape before the big explosion, Earth wins, and a firework show ends the movie. The End.

I know this movie doesn't seem serious now, but I still think it's a very good movie! And I'm not saying this just because Will Smith is my favourite actor... Well, maybe... But still, the movie is good! Yes, there's some scenes that seem to be funny, etc., but I think it's a great movie, it's fun, and entertaining, even tho it's old!

Review title: The alien disaster movies are back with a vengeance
Review_body: Roland Emmerich is undoubtedly a very skilled director who knows how to please the crowd. This movie has several good points and a few bad points which can be easily overlooked. The good points: 1-The movie maintains good emotional distance not letting the audience lose the plot. 2-The movie was skillfully directed. 3- the acting was brilliant [ especially will smith ] 4- The movie is a technical masterpiece [ the sound and the graphics and the effects are simply great] 5-The fight scenes were skillfully executed. 6- The movie has inspirational quotes. 7-The movies is a visual spectacle. Roland Emmerich's artistic background as a sculptor has helped him. The bad points: 1-One that stands out is the lack of resistance of the alien computers to the virus. 2-The spaceship is not detected till it crosses the moon.Well thats all the bad I could figure out. I think this movie will remain fresh in Hollywood record for a long time

Review title: Potentially great movie ruined by Pro American ending
Review_body: As I watched this movie on TV, having already seen it in theaters a few years ago, I was captivated by the movie, not able to change the channel. This was surprising since I thought that I hated the movie after having seen it in a theater.  But, the root of my hatred was clearly seen as the movie entered its final third.  The pro American ending was simply awful.  My old hatred was quickly reinforced, and I realized that these pro American films like Armageddon will never appeal to me.  The patriotic nature of these films adds nothing to them, it only limits their chance of success in markets other than the US.

This movie just seems to get worse every time you see it.  In the cinema, it's a bit of fun (if you don't don't think about it too much), and the visuals are very impressive.  They do not, however, make up for the stereotypical characters and almost sickening patriotism, which is especially obvious from the point of view of a non-American.  This movie has become the epitome of the big-budget blockbuster: plenty of escapist action, but no soul.

Review title: A huge pile of steaming dreck
Review_body: I hated this movie, it was a nice idea, but the execution was simply awful. This movie stole all the wrong bits from all the classic B movies from the past, and somehow failed to respect any of them. In addition to it's mangling of fifties B movie cliches, and implausible plot filled with insipid action sequences this movie tried, and failed to hold a light tone through a sequence where the world is nearly destroyed. Millions are slaughtered needlessly and then we're supposed to laugh just a few minutes later, I just couldn't buy any of that.  Will Smith is the only bright spot in an otherwise dreadful waste of a hundred million dollars.

I would grade this movie higher than a mere 6, were it not for the cheesy storyline.The one thing I liked though, was how they integrated area 51 into the movie.Especially the speech that Bill Pullman gives in the end, just before the main assault on the alien spacecraft may be very nice to all Americans out there, but that still leaves about 5.75 Billion other people on this planet...

Review title: I laughed. But not in a good way.
Review_body: To start, let me admit that the only reason I watched this movie was James Duval* (and the fact that it happened to air on the Dutch TV today). I do not generally like action movies, and while I can see that the special effects and destruction scenes may redeem ID4 in the eyes of people that do, I personally just couldn't get over the laughable plot.Yes, to be fair, I laughed - but it was the incredulous laugh of someone who can't believe his eyes. The scene that almost killed me was the one with the 'British' soldiers in the Iraqi desert. I'm not a native speaker, but despite all the 'bloody's and cups of tea that were tossed in for good measure, I don't think those actors were, either. I thought it couldn't get worse, until the naked, spear-brandishing African primitives showed up. The local McDonald's obviously had been photoshopped out, lest the viewer might think the Americans brought anything other than peace and democracy to the world....But really. I dislike neither America nor its inhabitants, but you *have* to realise how your overblown patriotism must look in the eyes of those with a more, erm, objective view on things. In fact, if the movie makers had been a bit more sensitive to actual history, they'd have had the alien ships exploding while our heroes were still desperately trying to come up with a plan, leaving everyone dumbstruck until someone finally realised, 'Damn! The Russians beat us to it'.Now *that* would have been a funny joke.Everyone already commented on the general ridiculousness of the main plot line, so I'll refrain from doing that. But let me just share one pet peeve that no one seems to have mentioned so far: the portrayal of science. In the actual world, scientists are intelligent people who know stuff you don't. In ID4 world, scientists are stupid, giggly weirdos who fail to make actual progress until the President and his cable guy decide to come barging in (in a sterile area, no less, supposedly spoiling decades of research, but who cares what those geeks are doing). THEY FAILED TO REALISE THAT THE PATTERNS ON THE SCREEN WERE A COMMUNICATION SIGNAL. I rest my case.Then there's the romance. The Will Smith/Vivica Fox romance was decent, though completely compiled from stock dialogue and clichéd scenes, but at least you get to feel like they deserve each other and vaguely hope for a happy ending for them. But Jeff Goldblum's character getting his wife back? She dumped him because he didn't do anything extraordinary, wants him back now that he's saved the day, and he happily encloses her in his arms as the credits roll - why doesn't he tell her that 'sorry, but she never accepted him for who he was, and it's too late now'? Do the writers really intend to convey the message that you truly only deserve to be loved for what you do, rather than for who you are? I'm sorry, but that doesn't seem very romantic to me.So, maybe I am overanalysing, because ID4 is really just a no-brainer, blah blah. But somehow, I can't see the fun of watching a movie while desperately trying to keep my neurons from firing - one might as well watch a movie with one's eyes closed. ('OMG you haters, you were just expecting WAY too much, if you had closed your eyes throughout the entire movie you'd have given it a 10/10!') By the way, you know what else killed me ded? This exquisite piece of irrefutable argumentation I stumbled upon in the comments: "Ok first of all the only people complaining about how bad this movie was are from other countries. here is a news flash for you. the US saved England's butts in world war 2."______ * Yes, I know he's not that great an actor, but girls can be superficial too. Next time, include moar shots plz?

Review title: Steaming pile of red, white, and blue crap
Review_body: Somehow, I was hoodwinked into watching this movie.  It immediately became apparent that what I was watching was merely one of a host of other jingoistic "God Bless America!" films.  I particularly enjoyed that bit where the British soldiers were sitting around, apparently twiddling their thumbs, until, lo and behold, here comes salvation draped in the Star Spangled Banner with a matching "Independence Day" cup from McDonald's. Apart from its thinly veiled pseudo-patriotism, this film had many other annoyances, not least of which was the miraculous compatibility between a Macintosh and an alien computer from 90 light-years away.  Eye candy at best, though wholly nauseating if your cynicism level is above 5mg/l.

This film is a great film, and the actors are also a great bonus for it, but, it lacks the extra punch needed to be an extraordinary film. There are so many films where aliens come to invade Earth and then we find a way to defeat them. Independence day had a great story and the visuals were one of the best I have seen, but it wasn't original enough.Will Smith plays his character well, but he just doesn't put enough effort into really owning the character. Not one of his best films at all.The "Aliens" and "Area 51" acts were good, not great. Although the visuals again were fantastic it lacks the magic to keep the film alive. Like I said it has a fantastic story and lots of different battle scenes, air battles, but the way they managed to defeat the "Aliens" and their shields, well that wasn't too good. I have seen much better endings and a much better way to defeat the villains.

I went to see this film with high expectations of a true sci-fi thriller, perhaps something along the lines of the TV series 'V', 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' and 'War of the Worlds', but much better given the sophistication of today's movie watchers and makers.  Instead we get dear old Bill Pullman doing his best with a ridiculous plot and script.  This film was a complete waste of money and time.  There should be something thought-provoking at least, even in a comedy, about the possibility of visitors from another planet.The special effects were OK, but totally unbelievable.  A spacecraft of that size would blot out all light to the city below.  And when it landed there would have to be seizmic implications.

Review_body: The actual direct source of the movie is Gordie Dickson's Hour of the Horde (c) 1970, although there's a good bit taken from the War of the Worlds, circa early sixties.From the back cover: "annihilating everything before it, a horde of monstrous space travelers were advancing through the stars. Either that or the action just needed to be more exciting, and some random boring scene here and there. Two, the special effects were great but the special effects for the alien creatures were not that great, they kind of looked like some kind of puppets. And three, there was one scene where a guy said to his dad that smoking is not healthy, and I was very happy he said that, until later he smoked for himself and liked it, and his dad eventually comes by and sees him smoking and says "What happened to smoking is not healthy", and than he says happily that he can get used it. I was furious on the inside when that happened. I want people to quit smoking, not to continue to smoke or want to! A kid or just someone regardless might get inspired to smoke by this. That is a maybe, and probably not, but possible.

Well, I can't honestly give this film a good review despite being a fan of Will Smith (well, he can be very annoying at times though and is better suited to other films) and Goldblum. The actors in it are not my favourites and this combined with what appeared to very bad acting really ruined the film for me. Bill Pullman, Robert Loggia and Adam Baldwin were absolutely awful. Was it just bad directing or just simply bad acting? Bill Pullman acted like he was in a comedy. His face expressions hilarious at times. I mean does he ever know when to put a serious face even at the thought the earth is about to end? I mean what was going on in his head? What was going on in the Director's head more importantly as this has some of the worse acting I have ever seen in a film. As for the story line, the thought of a virus being uploaded to a revolutionary alien ship like this was so unrealistic it made me laugh. What did they use again, a floppy disk? Is their security firewall that lame? Seriously? Who writes this crap? I could have walked out of the cinema at that point alone had it not been for some really good special effects which was the only factor to grab my attention. As for a single missile destroying a giant UFO that would kill an entire city if was to collapse on the earth, I don't think much thought went into the ending. I also like how Will Smith can just to fly an alien spaceship. I mean, is he from the matrix? Watchable for the special effects only. Everything else was a let down and I mean a serious let down. Now I like blockbuster films with special effects as much as anyone but it still needs to be believable and also well acted. This lacks this.

Review title: Is there anyone who STILL doesn't get this is a spoof?
Review_body: OK, let me lay out ALL the movies alluded to in Independence Day (actually I'll probably forget some)...opening scenes and giant space ships - the 1980's TV mini-series "V." The creatures - "Alien." Attacks on the giant ship, AND the mother ship - "Stars Wars." Using lights on a helicopter to signal "friendly signs" to the aliens - "Close Encounters" (and then it gets blown up - hilarious! and the pilot of the helicopter is the same actor in the same role in another movie about "friendly aliens" - 1984's "Starman."). "Data" from "Star Trek - Next Generation" as the crazy scientist leader of Area 51. Bill Pullman, AKA "Lone Star" from "Space Balls" as the President. Randy Quaid as the "suicide pilot" blowing up the big ship - same as Slim Pickens straight out of "Dr. Strangelove." "War of the Worlds" (giving their computer a "cold" like the aliens dying from earth "viruses"). The early scene of Randy Quaid's kids in the trailer park watching an old B&W movie "The Day the Earth Stood Still." Jeff Goldblum from "Earth Girls Are Easy." "Star Wars" type dogfights. The final race OUT of the mother ship before it explodes a la "Star Wars," Episode VI. HAS ANYONE WHO DOESN'T LIKE THIS MOVIE WATCHED ANY OTHER SCI-FI MOVIES? I laughed all the way thought it and still do.

I would have to say this is one of my least favorite movies of all time. trust me i have seen movies that are way worse, but i would give them a high rating for at least creativity and guts to try new ideas. but i hate this movie. And it isn't because i have any one specific problem with it, but more a compilation of little things that add up to one big lackluster let down. When i first saw this movie i loved it. but i was young and foolish. this movie is really bad from start to finish. the idea is there, and sometimes you get a glimpse of how this could have almost been a good movie. but bad plot structure, and a poorly written script ruin it.with that said i just cant justify giving it any lower of a score, because even with all of its flaws it can be entertaining to watch the first time. watch it if you want, but don't expect much. unless you like cheesy-sci-fi action movies with will smith. if you do, this is a 10/10 for you.

The plot in "Independence Day" isn't exactly hard to describe; some kind of alien race has decided to try to take over Earth, and after destroying most major cities in the world and crushing all counter-attacks, the U.S. finally prevails and kills them off. Any movie that can be explained well in one sentence - and I imagine that last sentence was pretty much the whole script - has a problem to start with. But, there are many simple action movies that still manage to be entertaining, given that they have a certain level of self-awareness (a movie like "Die Hard" is a good example). This movie, however, has the self-awareness of a two-year old. Not only that, it also over-uses every last one of the pathetic clichés that so many people connect Hollywood disaster-films with these days - flag-waving, macho guys trying to be funny (and failing miserably in the process), a score that is basically centered around different versions of the U.S. national anthem, the underdog who gets beaten down but prevails in the end, thus achieving the American Dream, the leader who is really not a man of politics, but a man of action, and of the people - everything. Watching a movie like this is interesting, because it is actually so dumb and totally unaware of its own absurdness that you can't parody it; it's already a parody of itself.The acting is bad, based on the fact that every character in this movie is insanely predictable. We all know within the first two seconds of seeing them exactly how they will behave until the very end. Of course Russell Casse (Randy Quaid), the alcoholic Vietnam veteran (who is the underdog I mentioned before) will get his revenge at the aliens who abducted him ten years before the attacks, of course he will prove the one's who have taunted him for so long wrong, and of course he will sacrifice his life for the sake of the United States of America - not the world - to become an incarnation of the archetype of the American Hero. Being a European, I have absolutely nothing against America myself, but it's no wonder how large parts of the world has a bad image of it when stuff like this is what they are basing their opinions on. (It's true that the director of the movie is actually German, but movies like this are controlled by studios, not directors.) All the other major characters' actions are just as predictable his Russell's, so I'm not going to go into them.You are not supposed to take movies like this too seriously, and I don't. But large parts of it is so mind-numbingly stupid that it ends up being provoking. There are tons of logical plot holes; one of the biggest ones being how Captain Steve Hiller (Will Smith) and David Levinson (Jeff Goldblum) manage to first travel into the alien mother ship, using one of the alien vehicles, obtained in Roswell, New Mexico in the '50s (the vehicle is located in Area 51 - where else?), and then downloading a virus into the main computer, causing the shields of the ships attacking Earth to go down, which allows the human forces to strike against them. This is absurd in many ways; first of all, don't the aliens have some kind of scan for spaceships entering their mother ship? Their technology is so ridiculously advanced there's no reason they shouldn't have one. But most of all, how the hell can Levinson just hook up his portable computer to their main computer and download the virus in a matter of seconds? These creatures have shields powerful enough to withstand any human weapon, but they are totally defenseless against a guy with his home computer? Normally, I don't find plot holes like that all that disturbing, but there's so many of them in this movie, you just can't help but. And in addition to that some special effects are really poor.Movies like "Independence Day" is the reason so many people detest Hollywood these days. It's dull and predictable, and has absolutely nothing new to offer. In addition to that, what it actually does offer, it offers in such a way that it feels like the heads of the studio responsible for it is actually sitting and laughing at for buying something as absurd as this. Sadly, the joke isn't on them, seeing as how this movie grossed more than $800 million worldwide. Maybe the human race does deserve to be annihilated after all.

Review title: Classic Fun That Never Gets Old
Review_body: Today the idea of aliens coming to earth to take over the world has become "cliche." But Independence Day was the first of its kind that took the darkness out of this genre. This is not to say that the movie does not have its sad moments, but this incredible cast brightens up the day.Bill Pullman plays the lovable fighter pilot who has become President. Jeff Goldblum plays a computer genius who is still in love with his wife (Margaret Colin), but are separated by professional differences. Jeff Goldblum's character, David Levinson joins up with his dad Julius (Judd Hirsh) in which the two add comic relief. Will Smith plays Captain Hiller who's dream is to fly a spaceship and lives with his striper girlfriend Jasmine (Viviva Fox). The list of great characters goes on and on. Each of this incredible cast's story will be affected by the alien invasion. They must put aside their differences in order to save the planet and in the process learn to respect each other. This theme is metaphor for life that in time of crisis, human beings can come together for the good of mankind. Overall just a great movie that constantly adds a new twist to the story. This movie is not trying to win an academy award but, if you take it for its worth, you will have a great time.

Review title: The spoiler warning is just for another movie I talk about
Review_body: Independence Day, a rehash of the 50's movie Earth v The Flying Saucers, is undoubtedly one of the most misunderstood movies of the century . . . Oh wait a second, no it's not.If you've ever seen the above mentioned 50's movie then you should be able to accurately guess the basic plot outline of this movie, if you haven't then you probably can still figure it out, aliens come, we don't understand why they're here, they blow us away, we figure out some way of beating them, beat them and go out for a big pancake breakfast to celebrate. The 50's movie had a few things going for it, such as paranoia about Soviet attack and air power, and a recent surge of interest in UFO's and the paranormal.ID4, in the 90's, couldn't capitalize on those, since the Soviets were gone and UFO's were just mainstream pop-culture by now, so the filmmakers decided that they would make the film overly patriotic, practically gushing sentiment and pride, as a cheap way to attract viewers. Here's a good rule of thumb, when a movie has to appeal to ones sense of patriotism just to get you to even think about going to see it, don't go see it.There are other irksome things about this movie, Will Smith's one liners, the absurd alien attack plan, the inaccuracy about Area 51(for starters Area 51 is not the airbase's official name), endless unsympathetic characters, and let's not forget the absolutely moronic way that the hero's disable the alien shields. If memory serves me, In Earth v The Flying Saucers we discover that a specific radio wave that causes the Saucer's guidance system to malfunction, while it's a leap of faith to believe that a simple radio wave can have such an amazing effect on a device designed to guide a complex spaceship across countless light-years, the thing they came up with in ID4 is absolutely unbelievable.On the plus side the special effects look great, even after all these years, which alone is a good reason to at least catch the movie when it's on TV. And certain elements of the movie work well. The destruction of monuments and cities is as unnerving as it should be. But it's just too little to make a difference.All in all not very good.

Review title: What are you all complaining about?
Review_body: I've noticed this a lot with films that make a lot of money - people seem to HATE them. Not just a small amount of dislike, real hatred. Why though? I saw this film years ago, as a child, and I'm NOT American, so the patriotism thing really should get to me... right? Sorry, but I'm able to look past that and see a good movie. People have a go at the script - but it works. There are some plot holes, but have you ever seen a film without one? People have a go at the acting - I saw nothing wrong with it. People say it's very 'God Bless America' and yes it is, but if it was 'God Bless The World' people would complain that it wasn't 'God Bless America' so really, look past that. It's got amazing special effects, great action, funny lines (Welcome to Earth is the best line ever! Though we have a family habit of repeating it every time we see an alien movie...), and it's a good film.It's not worth 10 out of 10 because it's not THAT good. But people are giving it 1 out of ten, and I have to say, come on, get over yourselves, it wasn't that bad.Anyway, it's not like any big budget movie has escaped the 'Haters'.See it, turn the volume up, laugh a bit, don't take it seriously. Enjoy it.

This movie is exciting, a good 90's classic. It's got good special effects, a good story line, and a good cast. Watching it took me back to the old days, before I was born! The best scene in the movie was the chase scene between Will Smith and the Alien. Will Smith really got out his funny catch phrases. And the CGI didn't even seem dated. The action in Independence Day was awesome. It never really slows down. There's a lot of destruction and a lot of people die in it. The soundtrack was really good. It gave the film something extra dramatic. Independence day is a great summer movie for any day of the week. Keep in mind there are adult situations that might not make it a good family film.

Review title: I've just watched for 100th time and still love
Review_body: Solid 9/10 could watch 100 times and more. Great cast, great film, great fun.

I just watched the DVD again, it's been a few years. This is STILL a great film - epic stuff, but without spanning decades to do it. The acting's still good, comic relief, tearjerkers, and morals, and an uplifting feeling. What more could you want? Makes me wish Bill Pullman was OUR president!Wlll Smith proves himself as a capable dramatic actor while showing off impressive comedic timing. Jeff Goldbloom, Judd Hersch, Harvey Fierstein... it's as though they found the very best of the not-quite-so-well-know superstars, picked 'em for talent more than box office draw, and gathered an experienced ensemble cast. But the ride doesn't stop there. Computer-generation Effects are at least as good as anything ILM put out in 1996, and a lot cleaner. You get to root and cheer for the good guys, lots of action, fun and drama. I don't see how anyone could fail to enjoy this film.

Became a huge fan of Roland Emmerich after this film released. Great cast with Pullman, Goldblum, Smith, Fox and Connick, Jr. One of the most entertaining and visualizing movies I have every seen. A must see for everyone, IMHO. Enjoy!

Review title: Worst movie that made a ton of money
Review_body: Independence Day, regardless of its box office rank, does not qualify as even a respectable film. For a number of reasons, primarily the poor script, poor plot, and just plan lack of originality.I mean come on, do you really believe an alien species that is hundreds of millennia more sophisticated then us, is going to be so vulnerable to destruction that a mere suicide attack from a jet plane could render their entire invasion a failure? Not to mention that an alien species cannot possibly have an aggressive mentality for by the time they reach this state of intelligence they would have destroyed themselves, hundreds of times over.And if they are this intelligent they would have nanobots to recycle their own waste. And they could simply have gathered the resources of their neighboring planets rather than travel hundreds of light years just to destroy a potential form of entertainment.The script is cliché 1990's, it incorporates many of the variables that are reminiscent of that decade, particularly nonsensical war-cries that do little to improve the movie watching experience and serves only to give the film an additional aura of ridiculousness. I cannot help but imagine the entertainment potential this film had, if only it were let's saymore serious- a sort of "War of the Worlds" type of film, although that was also a very inaccurate assessment of alien intelligence.

Review title: Not a good alien film, but not an awful one
Review_body: I can't believe some people give this a 10/10. It is not that sort of film. If you are looking for some intense action sequences, decent special effects, a below average story with average / below average acting, and a whole film that quite simply promotes the idea that Americans are Gods and should be worshipped by every other nation, this is your film. Bill Pullman's speech as president was awful. Will Smith's character unbelievable. Subplots all overworked. The idea of Jeff Goldblum's character is quite ridiculous. And basically the film is overlong. It's OK to watch once, not the worst film I have ever seen, but not what people say. 5 / 10Btw if you are into alien films i recommend these GOOD ones: -The Forgotten -War of the Worlds -Alien -Aliens and one of the best -Signs

It is movies like this that fuel the rest of the world's resentment towards America. Here you have $100 Million plus and the best that can be produced is a braindead, stupidly simplistic, bigoted story of how wonderful the USA is and "What would the world do without us?", complete with visually impressive yet emotionally devoid special effects.Contrary to this film's premise, the rest of the world would not be sitting around twiddling their thumbs waiting for America to save the day. Do we really expect that if a bunch of alien creatures that are smart enough to travel the universe and build incredible transports and weaponry technology decided they liked the look of our wee planet, that we would even have a hope of fighting back? Maybe you Yankees have an over-inflated perception of your abilities, but let's be reasonable here. Of course the film is about the triumph of the human spirit against all adversity, but really - how much more advanced is the super-evolved aliens' sense of "species pride" going to be? Do we really think twice when destroying an insect nest about the possibility of them getting us back?This film is riddled with incredibly dumb things. Even if there were some memorable characters (there aren't) and some moving moments (cheesy unsuccessful attempts) we would be prevented from enjoying them because the story is so foolish. I list a couple of examples:-An explosion that 'nukes' a city in seconds is not capable of being outrun and survived, in a tunnel, by a lone woman and the dog she loves very much.-Giant ships hovering over the world's major cities, when destroyed, manage to conveniently end up crashed out at sea, or in the mountains next to the city. Um, how?-A computer virus. How clever. Tell me, how did they link up with the mothership computer. Were the aliens conveniently using compatible computer systems and interfacing link-ups? Perhaps interested people could read Arthur C. Clarke's "3001: Final Odyssey" for an example of how this principle can be executed plausibly.Need I go on? I think not. I will simply conclude by saying that perhaps the makers of ID4 should think about what it was about "Star Wars" that moved them and millions of others a long time ago, and go back to the drawing board.Note: In New Zealand the promotional banners for ID4 contained a whopping great spelling mistake ("weren't" spelled "were'nt") Was this the case worldwide? I'd be interested to know. Just another example of the lack of intelligence associated with this film.

Review title: ID4 Accomplished All it Set Out to Do. No More, No Less.
Review_body: Reading the other reviews, I cannot help but feel as though people are taking this movie and, in fact, the CONCEPT of this movie far too seriously. First off, let me come right out and say that ID4 is the best disaster film ever made. Say what you will about Towering Inferno, Airport, Earthquake or the original Godzilla, ID4 does it better. The concept of the disaster film is, in essence, very simple. Have lots of characters representing many aspects of society and perspectives, all dealing with a common evil (be it natural, unnatural, supernatural, etc.) The idea is that people come together in times of crisis to confront a common foe. To do this well in a film requires a specific directorial touch in that, because the concept of the disaster film hangs on its multiple characters and, of course, the portrayal of the actual disaster, these elements must be rendered flawlessly. ID4 does this.If there is one word to describe ID4's aesthetic, technical and directorial design, it's polished. The special effects, which were NOT cutting edge in the mid 90s (contrary to what most think) looked precisely right. There is really only one way to show a wall of fire rushing down a city, and ID4 pretty much nailed it. The result of using only what was necessary in terms of effects and nothing more is that ID4 STILL looks good, almost a decade later. Also, the writing is concise, funny and direct. Nothing is extraneous or boring. And as far as the characters go, each is given ample screen-time and kept track of throughout the film. This is harder than it seems and, actually, it's also the reason why Soderbergh's Ocean's 11 is as polished as it is. The characters are all kept track of properly. So ID4 cannot be judged on its realism or any other extraneous factor. It is a marvelously entertaining disaster film. Of course it's oversimplified, of course it's not scientifically accurate. But that's why we go to the movies sometimes.

Review title: A first, and sadly not the last...
Review_body: ID4-  the first in a series of ultra-modern Hollywood eye candy garbage films that actually lack scripts.  This film was conceived as a series of explosions, spaceships, aliens, macho action sequences, and one-liners that are loosely connected by inane, brainless drivel to form a semblance of a connected whole.  For the majority of filmgoers, it works, because audiences don't like to think-  they like to stare mindlessly at the purty pictures while riding the dopamine high.  The "but the special effects were excellent" crowd loved this one, as did the "I don't like to think during a movie... I like to be entertained" bunch.  For anyone who does like to think, and respects SF as a genre capable of dealing with interesting and meaningful themes, avoid at all costs.  For everyone else... it has GREAT special effects!  Pant.  Drool.  1 out of 10.

Review title: No one involved in this film, cared, and it showed.
Review_body: This film was just plan awful. The actors were selected from a bin of dime a dozen Hollywood pretenders with formula characters.... Goldblum with his irritating one trick pony style of acting,... Will Smith introduces his regular guy super hero persona that he has regurgitated in every movie since,..(guys, acting means being a different person each movie). In general i got little impression of a sense of urgency or astonishment from the Hollywood pretenders, that ALIENS ARE INVADING!.It was impossible to overlook the countless obvious logical problems this movie had,... how did Smith know where to find his wife,... why did they have to get idiot volunteers to fight the aliens (the entire air force was gone, including retirees?),.. why didn't the missiles have the same explosive power each time as the final one,... how do you 'upload' a computer virus to an alien system without knowing their technology or protocol.There were just too many dumb script decisions,... Goldblum gets drunk and acts out because he's upset that fighting the aliens with Nuclear Weapons will hurt the environment(!), ...astoundingly idiotic,... The "president" decides to be a hero too, wow, there are no words to express how asinine that idea was,... The aliens have the technology to fly millions of light years in city sized ships yet they have to rely on our relatively archaic satellite systems in order to communicate with each other. I could go on and on and on.The fact that the entire premise or core idea of the movie was ridiculous, is no justification in glossing over obvious gaps in sense. Sci-fi movies are suppose to take us into fantasy, but not into stupidity. This movie was bad because not enough mental effort was put into it, quite typical of Hollywood. The sad truth is, that if this movie had been computer animated, say by Pixar, it would have been far more realistic and believable.

I don't care if the American president says they saved the World. They always do. I felt united with Jews, African Americans, Russian, Arabs and any human being after the film. We need more writers like this. Victor Orsini

Review title: For Pete's sake, it's a barn burner
Review_body: Some posters are over-intellectualizing Independence Day. It was an emotional barn burner, for Pete's sake. To worry about anything deeper than that is sort of like saying, "Are we having fun yet? -- i.e., you're just not getting it.Actually, looked at another way, it IS deep. It is a great movie for showing directly what it feels like to put aside petty differences for the time being. It reminds me of taking LSD: it takes for most people an extraordinarily strong entheogen like LSD to enter different "spaces" of expanded awareness; similarly, it takes an extraordinarily strong world event to bring people together. I experienced this in the Santa Cruz earthquake of 1989. For a short while, many petty interpersonal differences disappeared.
